newsitem.title: USA: COMEX copper ends lower on light volumes.
newsitem.headline: COMEX copper ends lower on light volumes.

text.p: COMEX copper futures ended slightly lower Tuesday, on light volume estimated at 7,500 lots, with little sense of direction evident this week, traders said.
"The Easter holiday is still affecting activity and the only sign of life is some small speculators rolling longs out of May into forward months, but I don't regard that as bearish," one trader said.
But U.S. February construction spending rose 2.3 percent, its biggest rise since March 1996, suggesting good ongoing demand for copper in that industry, analysts said.
COMEX May copper ended down 1.35 cent at 111.80 cents a pound, after recovering from session lows seen early at 110.20 cents.
Support is seen around last week's low at 109.80 cents, after the contract ran into resistance Monday around last week's high at 113.20 cents.

On the daily charts, momentum oscillators remained mixed, but May copper's five-day (weekly) moving average remains above its 21-day (monthly) average, and above its 55-day (quarterly) average, after a four-month long recovery from the sell off in the wake of last year's Sumitomo scandal.
The COMEX May/July backwardation eased to 3.10 cents from 3.5 cents Monday, with the LME cash-to-three month backwardation around $42.00 a tonne.
Copper stocks continue to fall with LME warehouse stocks down a further 6,226 tonnes Tuesday to 177,250 tonnes. Falls in LME stocks have been offsetting rises in COMEX stocks in recent weeks.
Better-than-expected activity in the U.S. housing and auto sectors in recent data suggests good gains in copper consumption in 1997, though supplies were seen rising this year also, analysts said.
